head.citation-title: Update on Intranasal Medications in Rhinosinusitis
head.abstracts: © 2017, Springer Science+Business Media New York.This review describes beneficial effects and adverse events of various intranasal medications in treating rhinosinusitis. Application of intranasal steroids has been described in treating all subtypes of adult rhinosinusitis, but reports are limited in pediatrics and mostly in acute pediatric subgroups resulted in benefits While saline irrigation is effective for patients with chronic rhinosinusitis without polyps and in pediatric acute rhinosinusitis, there is no evidence yet for saline drips and sprays. Application of intranasal antifungals and nasal irrigation with surfactant brings more harm than benefits. There is no evidence supporting the use of intranasal antibiotics. We also review influence of devices, methods, and patient head position on nasal and paranasal sinus drug delivery.

copyright.$: Copyright 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

reference.ref-fulltext: •• Fokkens WJ, Lund VJ, Mullol J, Bachert C, Alobid I, Baroody F, et al. European position paper on rhinosinusitis and nasal polyps 2012. Rhinology Suppl. 2012;50(23):1–298. The European Position Paper on Rhinosinusitis and Nasal Polyps 2012 is the update of evidence based position papers with regard to rhinosinusitis and nasal polyps. Management schemes based on the evidence are analyzed, summarized and proposed.

ref-title.ref-titletext: European position paper on rhinosinusitis and nasal polyps 2012

reference.ref-fulltext: • Lam M, Hull L, Imrie A, Snidvongs K, Chin D, Pratt E, et al. Interleukin-25 and interleukin-33 as mediators of eosinophilic inflammation in chronic rhinosinusitis. Am J Rhinol Allergy. 2015;29(3):175–81. Assessing sinus mucosal samples from 39 patients undergoing sinus surgery, this group demonstrated that epithelial-derived cytokines including IL-25 and IL-33 implicated in the initiation of T-helper 2 inflammation and eosinophilia in chronic rhinosinusitis. IL-25 and IL-33 overexpression was observed in eosinophilic inflammation.

ref-title.ref-titletext: Interleukin-25 and interleukin-33 as mediators of eosinophilic inflammation in chronic rhinosinusitis

IL-25 and IL-33 overexpression was observed in eosinophilic inflammation

reference.ref-fulltext: •• Chong LY, Head K, Hopkins C, Philpott C, Schilder AG, Burton MJ. Intranasal steroids versus placebo or no intervention for chronic rhinosinusitis. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2016;4:CD011996. A systematic review of the effects of intranasal steroids in treating patients with chronic rhinosinusitis. The group included 18 randomized controlled trials with a total of 2738 participants including both nasal polyps and without nasal polyps. Meta-analyses for all symptoms were performed. Size of benefit was assessed.

ref-title.ref-titletext: Intranasal steroids versus placebo or no intervention for chronic rhinosinusitis

Size of benefit was assessed

reference.ref-fulltext: •• Kirtsreesakul V, Khanuengkitkong T, Ruttanaphol S. Does oxymetazoline increase the efficacy of nasal steroids in treating nasal polyposis? Am J Rhinol Allergy. 2016;30(3):195–200. A randomized placebo-controlled trial in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps evaluating additive effects of oxymetazoline on intranasal steroids assessing nasal symptoms score, peak inspiratory flow index, nasal mucociliary clearance time, and total nasal polyps score. Any rebound congestion after oxymetazoline treatment was also analyzed.

ref-title.ref-titletext: Does oxymetazoline increase the efficacy of nasal steroids in treating nasal polyposis?

Any rebound congestion after oxymetazoline treatment was also analyzed

reference.ref-fulltext: • Neubauer PD, Schwam ZG, Manes RP. Comparison of intranasal fluticasone spray, budesonide atomizer, and budesonide respules in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with polyposis after endoscopic sinus surgery. Int Forum Allergy Rhinol. 2016;6(3):233–7. A randomized controlled trial in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps after endoscopic sinus surgery evaluating the effects of intranasal steroid when administered by three different devices. The group compared fluticasone nasal spray with budesonide respules via a mucosal atomization device and budesonide respules instilled via the vertex-to-floor while in the real practice off-label intranasal steroids are increasingly used other than traditional intranasal steroids.

ref-title.ref-titletext: Comparison of intranasal fluticasone spray, budesonide atomizer, and budesonide respules in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with polyposis after endoscopic sinus surgery

ref-info.ref-text: PID: 26679480, A randomized controlled trial in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps after endoscopic sinus surgery evaluating the effects of intranasal steroid when administered by three different devices. The group compared fluticasone nasal spray with budesonide respules via a mucosal atomization device and budesonide respules instilled via the vertex-to-floor while in the real practice off-label intranasal steroids are increasingly used other than traditional intranasal steroids

reference.ref-fulltext: • Harvey RJ, Kalish L, Oakley GM, Christensen JM, Snidvongs K, Sacks R. Irrigation based corticosteroids therapy is more effective than simple sprays in managing post-surgical chronic rhinosinusitis. American Rhinologic Society 2016 annual meeting San Diego, California, United States 2016. p. 30. A randomized controlled trial in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with and without nasal polyps after endoscopic sinus surgery evaluating the effects of a mometasone 2 mg dose delivered in either a 240 ml nasal irrigation solution or as 0.2 ml nasal spray once a day. All patients used both spray and irrigation with the active agent in one and placebo in the other.

ref-title.ref-titletext: Irrigation based corticosteroids therapy is more effective than simple sprays in managing post-surgical chronic rhinosinusitis

ref-info.ref-text: A randomized controlled trial in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with and without nasal polyps after endoscopic sinus surgery evaluating the effects of a mometasone 2 mg dose delivered in either a 240 ml nasal irrigation solution or as 0.2 ml nasal spray once a day
ref-info.ref-sourcetitle: A randomized controlled trial in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis with and without nasal polyps after endoscopic sinus surgery evaluating the effects of a mometasone 2 mg dose delivered in either a 240 ml nasal irrigation solution or as 0.2 ml nasal spray once a day.

reference.ref-fulltext: • Snidvongs K, Kalish L, Sacks R, Sivasubramaniam R, Cope D, Harvey RJ. Sinus surgery and delivery method influence the effectiveness of topical corticosteroids for chronic rhinosinusitis: systematic review and meta-analysis. Am J Rhinol Allergy. 2013;27(3):221–33. A review of the influence of sinus surgery and delivery methods on the effectiveness of intranasl steroids for chronic rhinosinusitis with meta-analyses. The application of corticosteroid to the nose does not always imply sinus delivery. The surgical state of the sinuses and the method or device used has been shown to heavily influence delivery to the sinus mucosa by this review.

ref-title.ref-titletext: Sinus surgery and delivery method influence the effectiveness of topical corticosteroids for chronic rhinosinusitis: systematic review and meta-analysis

affiliation.affilname: Faculty of Medicine, Khon Kaen University

coredata.dc:description: This review describes beneficial effects and adverse events of various intranasal medications in treating rhinosinusitis. Application of intranasal steroids has been described in treating all subtypes of adult rhinosinusitis, but reports are limited in pediatrics and mostly in acute pediatric subgroups resulted in benefits While saline irrigation is effective for patients with chronic rhinosinusitis without polyps and in pediatric acute rhinosinusitis, there is no evidence yet for saline drips and sprays. Application of intranasal antifungals and nasal irrigation with surfactant brings more harm than benefits. There is no evidence supporting the use of intranasal antibiotics. We also review influence of devices, methods, and patient head position on nasal and paranasal sinus drug delivery.
coredata.dc:title: Update on Intranasal Medications in Rhinosinusitis
